doc.after: As a child, Nagle had a Pomeranian and a Bulldog, but was promised she could have a larger dog once her schooling was completed.[13] In 1913 her dream came to fruition with the purchase of her first Irish Wolfhound, Manin Michael, for Â£5.[13] James Nagle subsequently registered the dog with the Kennel Club, before it was transferred to the ownership of Mr and Mrs Nagle, and its name changed to Sir Michael of Sheppey in May 1917.[6] Food shortages during the First World War resulted in an official prohibition on dog breeding, but Nagle ignored it and bred her first litter from a bitch called Lady Alma of Sheppey.[13][b]
